critical.description: The Brave Conversion Engine (PRO) plugin for WordPress is vulnerable to Authentication Bypass in all versions up to, and including, 0.7.7. This is due to the plugin not properly restricting a claimed identity while authenticating with Facebook. This makes it possible for unauthenticated attackers to log in as other users, including administrators.

The Case Theme User plugin for WordPress is vulnerable to Authentication Bypass in all versions up to, and including, 1.0.3. This is due to the plugin not properly logging a user in with the data that was previously verified through the facebook_ajax_login_callback(). This makes it possible for unauthenticated attackers to log in as administrative users, as long as they have an existing account on the site, and access to the administrative user's email.

The Search & Go - Directory WordPress Theme theme for WordPress is vulnerable to Authentication Bypass via account takeover in all versions up to, and including, 2.7. This is due to insufficient user validation in the search_and_go_elated_check_facebook_user() function This makes it possible for unauthenticated attackers to gain access to other user's accounts, including administrators, when Facebook login is enabled.

The Felan Framework plugin for WordPress is vulnerable to improper authentication in versions up to, and including, 1.1.4. This is due to the hardcoded password in the 'fb_ajax_login_or_register' function and in the 'google_ajax_login_or_register' function. This makes it possible for unauthenticated attackers to log in as any existing user on the site, if they registered with facebook or google social login and did not change their password.

The Bravis User plugin for WordPress is vulnerable to Authentication Bypass in all versions up to, and including, 1.0.0. This is due to the plugin not properly logging a user in with the data that was previously verified through the facebook_ajax_login_callback(). This makes it possible for unauthenticated attackers to log in as administrative users, as long as they have an existing account on the site, and access to the administrative user's email.

A stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Facebook Chat module of Live Helper Chat v4.60 allows attackers to execute arbitrary web scripts or HTML via injecting a crafted payload into the Surname parameter under the Recipient' Lists.

A stored cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in the Facebook registration page of Live Helper Chat v4.60 allows attackers to execute arbitrary web scripts or HTML via injecting a crafted payload into the Name parameter.

Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') vulnerability in Nextendweb Nextend Facebook Connect allows Stored XSS. This issue affects Nextend Facebook Connect : from n/a through 3.1.19.

cve.summary: Recent vulnerability analysis for Facebook reveals a stable trend with 10 CVEs reported in 2025. A significant portion of these vulnerabilities are critical and high severity authentication bypass issues found in various WordPress plugins that integrate with Facebook for user login. Additionally, several medium severity cross-site scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities have been identified in Facebook-related modules and plugins. These findings highlight the importance of secure integration practices for third-party applications utilizing Facebook's services to prevent unauthorized access and data manipulation.

compliance.overall_summary: Meta (Facebook) demonstrates a strong commitment to security and compliance, particularly for its Cloud API and Workplace platforms. The Cloud API is ISO 27001 certified, validating its information security management system. Workplace holds multiple certifications, including ISO 27001 for ISMS, ISO 27018 for PII protection in cloud services, and undergoes annual SOC 2 audits, summarized in a SOC 3 report, confirming independent third-party validation of its security practices. Additionally, Workplace is GDPR compliant, providing data processing protections to its customers.

items.title: German Court Rules on 2019 Facebook Data Breach Compensation
items.description: A German court has ruled that users affected by the 2019 data breach, which exposed personal information of 533 million users through scraping, can seek compensation without proving specific damages. Meta disputes the ruling, stating their systems were not hacked.

items.title: Alleged Theft of 1.2 Billion Facebook Accounts by 'ByteBreaker'
items.description: A hacker known as 'ByteBreaker' claims to have stolen data from 1.2 billion Facebook accounts, including personally identifiable information, and is reportedly selling it on underground forums. Facebook has not confirmed the alleged breach, but if verified, it would be one of the largest personal data leaks in history.

items.title: 2021 Facebook Data Leak Exposes 533 Million Users
items.description: Personal data from 533 million Facebook users, including phone numbers, full names, locations, and email addresses, was leaked online. Facebook attributed this to a scraping vulnerability patched in 2019, leading to a significant GDPR fine for Meta in November 2022.

items.title: Cambridge Analytica Harvests 50 Million Facebook Profiles
items.description: Cambridge Analytica harvested personal information from over 50 million Facebook profiles without authorization to build voter profiles for political advertising. This major scandal resulted in a $725 million settlement in 2023.

items.title: Facebook Security Issue: 30 Million Access Tokens Stolen
items.description: Attackers exploited a vulnerability in Facebook's 'View As' feature between July 2017 and September 2018, stealing access tokens from 30 million users. This allowed access to names, contact details, and other profile information for a significant portion of those affected.

items.title: Facebook Stored 600 Million User Passwords in Plain Text
items.description: It was revealed in March 2019 that Facebook had been storing up to 600 million user passwords in plain text files, accessible to over 2,000 employees, with records dating back to 2012. Facebook subsequently worked to resolve this severe security flaw.

items.title: 540 Million Facebook Records Exposed on Public Server
items.description: In April 2019, over 540 million Facebook records, including account names and Facebook IDs, were discovered on a publicly accessible server. The data was eventually secured after efforts to contact the hosting company.

items.title: 267 Million Facebook Accounts Exposed on Dark Web
items.description: Personal data from over 267 million Facebook users was detected on the dark web in December 2019, potentially exposed for up to two weeks. An additional 42 million records were found in March 2020 by the same criminal organization.

incidents.summary: Multiple significant security incidents and data breaches have affected Facebook (now Meta) over the years, ranging from data scraping vulnerabilities to unauthorized access of user information and plain-text password storage. These incidents have led to large-scale exposure of personal data, legal actions, and substantial financial settlements.
